titleStmt.title: Newes out of Germanie. A most wonderfull and true discouse of a cruell murderer, who had kylled in his life tyme, nine hundred, threescore and odde persons among which six of them were his owne children begotten on a young woman which he forceablie kept in a caue seuen yeeres, with the manner how he was taken, and the aboundaunce of wealth that was found in the said caue: executed at Berkessell on the 14. of Iune. Translated and published according to the Dutch and French coppyes. By G.P. 1584.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 12 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 8 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

titleStmt.title: Newes out of Germanie. A most wonderfull and true discouse of a cruell murderer, who had kylled in his life tyme, nine hundred, threescore and odde persons among which six of them were his owne children begotten on a young woman which he forceablie kept in a caue seuen yeeres, with the manner how he was taken, and the aboundaunce of wealth that was found in the said caue: executed at Berkessell on the 14. of Iune. Translated and published according to the Dutch and French coppyes. By G.P. 1584.
titleStmt.author: Pen, George.

publicationStmt.publisher: [By J. Wolfe] for George Pen, dwelling at Ipswich,

notesStmt.note: Place of publication, printer's name and date of publication from STC.
Concerning the life, capture and execution of Christeman Gempertinga.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A mo≈øt wonderfull and true di≈øcour≈øe of a cruell murderer, who had kylled in his life tyme, nine hundred, three≈øcore and odde per≈øons among which ≈øix of them were his owne children, begotten on a young woman which he forceablie kept in a Caue ≈øeuen yeeres, with the manner how he was taken, and the aboundaunce of wealth that was found in the ≈øaid Caue: executed at Berke≈ø≈øell on the 14. of Iune.
Tran≈ølated and publi≈øhed according to the Dutch and French Coppyes. By G.P. 1584.
‚ùß Imprinted for George Pen, dwelling at Ip≈øwich.

div.head: ‚ùß A Letter written to a noble per≈øonage of the Cittie of Mentz, by a Gentleman of credit, who ≈øawe this murderer executed.
div.p: RIght honourable and my e≈øpeciall good freend, I haue not at this time any newes wherewith to acquiant you, but only this ≈øtraunge and admirable occa≈øion which lately happened: the truth whereof I tru≈øt my credit is ≈øufficient with your honour to confirme, and the rather, for that I not only heard the murderers examination, but was al≈øo an eye witne≈ø≈øe of his death. And albeit it may ≈øeeme incredible, yet thus much I can a≈ø≈øure you, that I ≈øaw the ≈øcrole which was found in the murtherers Caue, wherin he had written the names of al one that he had murdred, and I heard him al≈øo affirme it with his owne mouth. The di≈øcour≈øe thereof followeth, which I commit to your iudgement, and ≈øo I commend your honor to the heauenly protection.

div.head: ‚ùß A rare and straunge Di≈øcour≈øe, of a notorious and cruell Murderer, named Chri≈øteman Gempertinga, who leading a bloody life of longe time, and beeing at la≈øt apprehended therefore confe≈ø≈øed that in his life time he had ≈ølaine nine hundred, three ≈øcore and foure per≈øons, and entended to murder ≈øtill, till he had made vp the account of a thou≈øand. For which horrible murders, hee was executed in the Towne of Berke≈ø≈øell, neere to the Cittie of Mentz in Germanie.
div.p:
IN the Forre≈øt of Fra≈øburg, within a league of Berke≈ø≈øell, there liued for the ≈øpace of 13. yeeres one Chri≈øteman Gempertinga of Corpen, two leagues di≈øtaunce from Collen, who≈øe only maintenauÃÑce was by robbing and ≈øpoyling of the pa≈ø≈øingers, and ≈øuch
a fit and commodious place for his purpo≈øe he had prouided him≈øelfe of, as he might at plea≈øure di≈øcerne them that traueiled on the hye wayes, either to Mentz, Dietenhau≈øen, Treuers, or Duche de Luxenbourg, to which places Merchauntes did ordinarily traffique, becau≈øe they were Townes of great commoditie for their affaires. And as they trauailed thorow this Forre≈øt, he and his companions would ≈øet vppon them, and hauing robbed them of their goods and trea≈øure, would likewi≈øe di≈øpoyle them of their liues, and afterward cau≈øe them to bee throwen into a deepe pit in the Forre≈øt, which he had ordained for the purpo≈øe: as for theyr apparell, weapons and ≈øuch like, he caryed to his Caue, which in time was ≈øo well ≈øtored with Harquebu≈øes, Swordes, Murrians, Parti≈øans and Cor≈ø≈øetes, that a great ≈øtrength could not haue ouer come
him and his companyons.

And for the goods, which he tooke from the Merchauntes and pa≈ø≈øengers, his Caue was ≈øo well furni≈øhed there with, beeing of all ≈øorts of Merchandi≈øe, and wares belonging to the Allemaignes and other Nations: as the quantitie thereof was iudged ≈øufficient to furni≈øh a Fayre and the value thereof e≈øteemed more worth, then 70000. Florins of gold of Allemaigne. And be≈øides, there was founde in his Caue al≈øo when he was taken, ≈øo great ≈øtore of wine, bread, fle≈øh, rey≈øons, & figs, as would haue ≈øuffi≈øed him for one whole yeere. Among≈øt all the pa≈ø≈øengers that traueiled thorowe this Forre≈øt, it chaunced one day, that a proper womaÃÑ of Popert neere ye Rhine A Coopers daughter went to ≈øee her brethren & had occa≈øion to pa≈ø≈øe that way, this villanous murderer hauing e≈øpyed her, made ha≈øt to her, and hauing di≈øpoiled her of ≈øuch thinges as ≈øhe had
about her, intended to murder her, as he had doon all the other: but being ouercome with the ≈øight of her fayre face and body, helde hys handes, and intreated her to keepe him coÃÑpany there in that place, and be contended with that kinde of life which he v≈øed, otherwi≈øe he would likewi≈øe kil her. The woman fearefull of death, and ≈øeeing the horrible ma≈ø≈øacre of dead bodyes in the pit before her, whom ≈øhe ≈øhould keepe company if ≈øhe denyed his reque≈øt: con≈øented vnto him, and promi≈øed neuer to betray or reueale him to any, whereby his life might ≈øtand in any hazard. On this condition he lead her with him into his Caue and there ≈øhe liued with him for the ≈øpace of 7. yeeres, in which time ≈øhe had 6. Children by him, which ≈øo ≈øoone as they were borne, hee would take them and breake theyr neckes and pull them by the feete and head to ≈øtreatch them in length and afterward would goe hange
them vp on a high place that he had prouided for the nonce: and then he would ≈øtand looking on them, and ≈øeeing the winde to make them waue vp and downe, this merciles villaine would ≈øay: Daunce daunce my loouing Children, for Gempertinga your Father dooth ≈øounde you a daunce. It was a meruailous greefe and great hart breaking to the poore woman, to ≈øee her tender Infantes v≈øed ≈øo de≈øpitefully by theyr owne Father, and gladly ≈øhe would haue beene rid of that kinde of lyfe, but that ≈øhe could not get thence by any meanes: for hee had tyed her with a chaine, and ≈øhe could goe no furder then the Chaine gaue her libertie, which pollicie he v≈øed, lea≈øt ≈øhe ≈øhould e≈øcape away while hee and his companions were abroad, and ≈øo his dealings might be di≈øcouered. After that he had robbed and killed for a long ≈øea≈øon, he grewe doubtfull of his companions, and euery day did more and more mi≈øtru≈øt
them: ≈øo that at length he deui≈øed a meane to ea≈øe his doubt, and one day making merry among≈øt them, he conuayed in theyr meate and drinke ≈øuch a violent and extreame kinde of poy≈øon, as they all dyed thereof within 5. or ≈øix houres after: which he perceiuing, threwe them into the pit to the other bodyes that they had murdered.

When he was thus rid of his companions, and had no body left with him but the woman, he wexed ≈øomwhat doubtful of her lykewi≈øe: but God willing to reueale the horrible villainies of this murderer, cau≈øed the woman to be verie importunat in reque≈øt to him, that ≈øhe might go ≈øee her freends, and wrought al≈øo in his minde ≈øo accordingly, that hee gaue her leaue to goe, a≈ø≈øuring him ≈øelfe on her promi≈øe, that ≈øhe would neuer reueale him. She went and ≈øawe her Parents, and returned againe without vttering any worde of him, which made him the more
willing to ≈øuffer her to go againe, and entring the ≈øtreetes of Berke≈ø≈øel, ≈øhe ≈øawe little children playing, the ≈øight wherof, and the remembrance how villainou≈øly her owne children were murdred, cau≈øed her to fal into extreeme complaintes and pa≈ø≈øions, at la≈øt ≈øhe brake foorth into the≈øe dolorous ≈øpeeches. O God which doo≈øt maintaine all thinges, and from whome the death of my children cannot be hidden, & who knowe≈øt the promi≈øe I haue made by con≈øtraint: beholde me in mercie, and pittie the angui≈øhes I haue endured in my fle≈øhe and blood.

The≈øe her complaintes were ≈øo pittiful both in ≈øhew & hearing, yt many gathered about her to know the cau≈øe of her lamentations, and very earne≈øt they were with her to vnder≈øtand the cau≈øe of her pa≈ø≈øionate afflictions: but they could by no meanes preuaile in theyr inteÃÑts, for that ≈øhe ≈øayde, ≈øhe had prote≈øted ≈øecrecie of her greefes by ≈øolempne
oath, and ≈øhe would not vtter them to any. Some of them that ≈øtoode by & heard her wordes, infourmed the Iu≈øtices in ye Towne of the matter, whervpon ≈øhe was brought before them, and there ≈øhe coÃÑtinued in the ≈øame ob≈øtinate opinion ≈øhe dyd before: neuerthele≈ø≈øe, they labored ≈øtyl with her, & gaue her to vnder≈øtand, that a wilful oath might endammage her ≈øoule, and by reuealing it, ≈øhe might e ‚Ä¢ cape many daungerous threatninges for the contrary. By which per≈øwa≈øions ≈øhe animated her ≈øelf, and from the beginning to the end ≈øhe di≈øcour≈øed the whole circum≈øtaunce by particulers, of the murderer and his lyuing: wherevppon, the Iu≈øtices concluded with her, what cour≈øe ≈øhe ≈øhould take to preuayle in this matter, both to betray the murderer, and ≈øaue her ≈øelf blamele≈ø≈øe. Not long after they put in readines thyrtie wel appointed Soldiours, who ≈øhould folow the woman a farre off tyl they fouÃÑd the
Caue: and ≈øhee (according to the Iu≈øtices direction (tooke with her a bagge of Pea≈øe, which ≈øhe ≈øcattered along the way as ≈øhe went, by which meanes the Soldiours could not mi≈ø≈øe of the right way to the Caue. When ≈øhe came to the Caue, the murderer was very glad of her returne, and ie≈øting familiarly with her, at la≈øt he layde him downe on the ground, and laide his head in her lappe, where by her rubbing and ≈øoft ≈øcratching it, he fel a ≈øleepe. Within a whyle after, the Soldiors came to the Caue, and finding him thus ≈øleeping, they laid handes on him, and bound him ≈øo, that he could not re≈øi≈øt them: which hee perceyuing, cried out, O thou di≈øloyall whore, it is long ≈øince I mi≈ødoubted this thy trechery, & I thought to haue ≈øped thee with the re≈øt of thy fellowes. The Soldiours brought him with them to Berke≈ø≈øel, where being put to the torment, he confe≈ø≈øed
all his former villainies, & that he had murdered 964. per≈øons, and howe he intended to continew in murdering ≈øtyl, tyl he had ≈ølaine ≈øo many as came to a thou≈øand, & then he would murder no more: and to verifie his wordes, the Soldiours pre≈øented the Iu≈øtices a ≈øcrowle, wherein the names were written by his owne hand, of all them that he had murdered, and on what ≈øeueral dayes he murdered them. Heervpon he was condemned, and had his legges and armes, and bones broken with an yron in≈øtrument fit for the purpo≈øe, and afterward was laide on a Cart wheele without the Towne (as it is the maner in other Countries) where he liued for the ≈øpace of nine daies after, being daily ≈øu≈øtained with drinke and meat, to maintayne his lyfe in ≈øome extreame paine: and all the goodes that were found in his Caue, were brought to the Towne, and they
and the woman kept in holde, the Magi≈øtrates being not as yet re≈øolued how to deale with them. It is thought, that had not the Soldiors found him ≈øo ≈øleeping, they could hardly haue taken him, he had ≈øo many Caliuers, Harguebu≈øes, and Dags ready charged in his Caue, & was of him≈øelfe ≈øuch a ≈øtoute, ≈øtrong and actiue man, & the place where he was, did ≈øerue him in all re≈øpects able to re≈øi≈øt a great number.

The con≈øideration of this ≈øtraunge and mon≈øtrous di≈øcour≈øe, I committee to your honours good con≈øtruction, accounting it a parte of my duety, to make your honour acquainted with any notable thing I can heare of: And ≈øo I humbly take my leaue.
